Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Exploring the Design and Implementation of Buyout Programs in Post-Disaster Settings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project examines how local government agencies develop, design, and implement home buyout programs in the United States. Home buyout programs are intended to permanently reduce vulnerability from disasters by relocating residents away from areas that are prone to repeated hurricanes, flooding, or other hazards. Buyouts are typically funded by the federal government but implemented by state, county, or municipal agencies. How these programs are designed, communicated to the public, and carried out determines whether they achieve their purpose of mitigating against future disasters. Currently, however, local government agencies frequently struggle to implement buyouts because guidelines are unclear and there is an absence of agreed, well-founded practices for this type of program. Even with this limitation, buyouts are increasingly considered the best solution for improving the future for communities that experience repeated disasters. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare with benefits that will inform planning to improve the resilience of United States communities, in particular to flooding. This project is funded through the RAPID grant mechanism to examine the home buyout program currently in process following the severe 2017 flooding in Harris County, Texas, which includes the city of Houston.

This project examines at the micro level, the critical processes in the initial phases of post-disaster home buyout programs, examining decisions and outcomes in Harris County, Texas. This project uses semi-structured, qualitative interviews with government stakeholders and affected residents, observational data, and content analysis of internal and public program documents to address two key theoretical questions identified in the literature. First, it will further the understanding of the nature of buyout programs, as they are designed as mitigation programs and perceived as such by government agencies, but implemented in the time-compressed recovery period and viewed by residents as vehicles of recovery. Secondly, it will contribute to the literature on post-buyout land use and management by examining how implementing agencies plan to reintegrate buyout properties into public ownership and use.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study documented the internal decision-making processes of the buyout implementing agency in Harris County Texas following Hurricane Harvey, which is an aspect of buyouts that has been overlooked in research on buyouts to date. In November 2018 and December 2019, we conducted interviews with key government officials associated with the buyout implementing agency and residents identified by the implementing agency as eligible to participate in the buyout program. In total, we interviewed ten homeowners and ten government officials. Additionally, we conducted site visits to twelve buyout neighborhoods and observed post-buyout land uses as well as elements of recovery.

Local implementing agencies play a pivotal role in buyout program design and implementation; this study greatly contributed to our previously limited knowledge on how these agencies operate. Results from this research identified a tension between buyout programs that are designed and funded as mitigative actions yet perceived as recovery tools for impacted homeowners. This tension, alongside the delays in receiving federal funding, contributes to program attrition. Additionally, this work echoed similar challenges with post-buyout open space management as observed in previous studies such as the financial burden of maintaining the open space and lack of community engagement in identifying post-buyout land uses. 

Findings from this study informed four conference presentations, one peer-reviewed journal article, one practitioner workshop, and two practitioner publications. The work has been disseminated to communities of interest through several avenues. The PI and Co-PIs authored two publication for EfficientGov, which reaches local government officials across the U.S., on the key findings that emerged from the first data collection efforts. Additionally, this work was presented to a Texas Housing Recovery summit, convened in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey, to track recovery and mitigation across the state.  The journal article will be shared with the Harris County Flood Control District once it is published. Additionally, this project provided opportunities for undergraduate student training and professional development as two students assisted with transcription and data analysis and one masters student from the University of North Texas assisted with interviews and in-the-field data collection.
